title: HMS Invincible (1869)
text:
HMS "Invincible" was a <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> <a href="Ironclad%20warship">ironclad</a> <a href="battleship">battleship</a>. She was built at the Napier shipyard and completed in 1870. Completed just 10 years after , she still carried sails as well as a <a href="steam%20engine">steam engine</a>.
Armament.
The "Audacious" class was armed with ten muzzle-loading guns, supported by four muzzle loaders. These were located in a <a href="Broadside%20%28naval%29">broadside</a> pattern over a two-<a href="Deck%20%28ship%29">deck</a> battery amidships—this was the area of the ship least affected by its motion, and made for a very stable gun platform.
Early career.
For the first year of her career, she was a guardship at <a href="Kingston%20upon%20Hull">Hull</a>, before being replaced by her sister . She was then transferred to the <a href="Mediterranean%20Sea">Mediterranean</a>, where she served until 1886. She was sent to <a href="Cadiz">Cadiz</a> in 1873 to prevent ships seized by republicans during the civil war in <a href="Spain">Spain</a> from leaving harbour. She rejoined the Mediterranean Fleet in 1878 under the command of Captain <a href="Lindsay%20Brine">Lindsay Brine</a>, but her poor state of seamanship attracted the ire of the commander-in-chief, <a href="Geoffrey%20Hornby">Geoffrey Hornby</a>. In early 1879 "Invincible" blundered badly, putting two ships at hazard, and Brine was court-martialled. Though acquitted, Brine was relieved by Captain <a href="Edmund%20Fremantle">Edmund Fremantle</a>. She was <a href="Beauchamp%20Seymour">Admiral Seymour</a>'s temporary <a href="flagship">flagship</a> at the 1882 <a href="Bombardment%20of%20Alexandria%20%281882%29">bombardment of Alexandria</a> because his normal one, , <a href="Draft%20%28hull%29">drew</a> too much to enter the inner harbour. She provided men for the <a href="naval%20brigade">naval brigade</a> that was subsequently landed and she also provided men for <a href="Charles%20Beresford">Charles Beresford</a>'s naval brigade in the <a href="Sudan">Sudan</a> campaign of 1885.
Later career and shipwreck.
She made a trip to China in 1886 to carry out a new crew for "Audacious" before becoming the guardship at <a href="Southampton">Southampton</a> until 1893. Her engines were removed in 1901 when she became a depot ship at <a href="Sheerness">Sheerness</a> for a <a href="destroyer">destroyer</a> <a href="flotilla">flotilla</a>. She was renamed HMS "Erebus" in 1904, a name that she bore until 1906, when she was converted into a training ship at <a href="Portsmouth">Portsmouth</a> for engineering <a href="Armed-forces%20artificer">artificer</a>s and was renamed "Fisgard II" ("Audacious" had been renamed "Fisgard" in 1904).
On 17 September 1914, she sank during a storm off <a href="Portland%20Bill">Portland Bill</a> with the loss of 21 of her crew of 64. She was being towed from Portsmouth to <a href="Scapa%20Flow">Scapa Flow</a> where she was to act as a receiving ship for seamen newly mobilised for <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>. She now lies upside down with the bottom of the hull about below sea level.
HMS "Fisgard II" is a Designated vessel under schedule 1 of The Protection of Military Remains Act 1986 (Designation of Vessels and Controlled Sites) Order 2012.
